headline: CTO & Entrepreneur for the past 8 years
about:
Entrepreneur and CTO for more than 8 years, I am passionate about technical leadership and team management.

During my experience at FairMoney I had the opportunity to build, organize, manage a technical team of 35 people and develop a banking product used by more than 2 million customers that generates more than 100 million euros in revenue.

Technically my expertise is mainly backend (Rails, NestJS) and infra (AWS, terraform) with the implementation of continuous deployment (test strategy, trunk-based development). I was also able to occasionally develop web and mobile frontends (React, Expo, Java).

Personally I am striving to improve everyday by reading books / articles.
Favourite books: Accelerate, Team topologies, Domain Driven Design, Clean Architecture, Designing Data-Intensive Applications
Favourite newsletters: Software Lead Weekly, Tech.Rocks, The Pragmatic Engineer

publications.title: AI Act: what are the implications for sensitive sectors in Europe?
Similarity-based data mining for online domain adaptation of a sonar ATR system
publications.summary: Due to the expensive nature of field data gathering, the lack of training data often limits the performance of Automatic Target Recognition (ATR) systems. This problem is often addressed with domain adaptation techniques, however the currently existing methods fail to satisfy the constraints of resource and time-limited underwater systems. We propose to address this issue via an online fine-tuning of the ATR algorithm using a novel data-selection method. Our proposed data-mining approach relies on visual similarity and outperforms the traditionally employed hard-mining methods. We present a comparative performance analysis in a wide range of simulated environments and highlight the benefits of using our method for the rapid adaptation to previously unseen environments.

experiences.title: Tech Lead
experiences.jobDescription:
As Tech Lead in the Web Experience crew, I drove the technical roadmap and execution to enhance the frontend foundation and streamline development workflows, empowering engineering teams to build high-quality features efficiently. A major initiative was Merge Platform, a large-scale unification project consolidating four separate platforms (Liquids, Dry, LNG, LPG) into a single, streamlined interface. This involved deep codebase refactoring to replace four distinct applications‚Äîeach with unique conditions and URLs‚Äîwith a unified platform for the Kpler Terminal, simplifying development and improving user experience.

Beyond platform improvements, we also delivered two key product MVPs aligned with business priorities:

updates.postText:
üîç Inspired by Scott Sherwood Ph.D. latest thoughts on Google‚Äôs ADK and the future of multi-agent systems, I took some time to reflect on the coexistence (or competition?) between A2A (Agent-to-Agent) and MCP (Model Context Protocol).

The more I explore it, the more it feels like the boundary between the two is as much conceptual as it is technical.

üí° My (still developing) intuition: yes, there‚Äôs overlap ‚Äî but also clear structural limits.

üåê Let me try an imperfect analogy: it‚Äôs a bit like comparing the Internet to a website.
For years, we‚Äôve watched giants like Google, YouTube, AWS, now ChatGPT centralize the web. These services are so polished and reliable, they cover 90% of real-world usage.
But around them, the chaotic, decentralized web continues to exist ‚Äî and that‚Äôs often where the next wave of innovation begins.

üõ†Ô∏è MCP delivers a centralized, efficient, and well-orchestrated experience. Ideal for clearly scoped problems.
ü§ù A2A is messier to implement ‚Äî but it enables open, autonomous architectures, where intelligence can emerge from distributed coordination.

And maybe that‚Äôs the key: inside companies, we try to MCP-ify everything ‚Äî but in the real world, we constantly deal with clients, partners, vendors, and brokers‚Ä¶

That space ‚Äî where structure meets unpredictability ‚Äî might be a natural fit for A2A.

üß≠ My bet? MCP will lead in standardized, productized systems.
But A2A might be what we need for intelligent interoperability across unpredictable, loosely coupled environments.

ü§Ø And let‚Äôs be honest‚Ä¶ the real twist is that each approach can encapsulate the other.
So how do you predict the future when everything can wrap everything else? Recursive architecture inception at its finest.

üôè Thanks again @Scott Sherwood for sparking the reflection ‚Äî I‚Äôm excited to keep exploring this at Kpler and beyond.

üîÑ Curious to hear how others see it:
‚Äî Can A2A and MCP coexist long-term?
‚Äî Or are we heading toward a protocol war?

headline: CEO & Co-Founder Rialto | Building Global Stablecoin Payment Infrastructure
about:
I am an entrepreneur with over a decade of experience building regulated financial infrastructure at the intersection of blockchain and traditional finance.

As Co-Founder & CEO of Rialto, I lead a regulated digital asset service provider bridging stablecoins and fiat payments across 25+ currencies and 20+ networks, enabling global businesses to transact seamlessly.

Previously, I co-founded Atlendis Labs, a capital-efficient DeFi credit protocol that connects institutional liquidity to real-world borrowers, helping fintechs and SMEs access alternative financing at scale.

My expertise spans:
- Company building & leadership ‚Äî scaling ventures from 0 to institutional adoption.
- Fundraising & investor relations ‚Äî raising multi-million rounds and managing stakeholders.
- Regulation & compliance ‚Äî navigating VASP registration, MiCA, and AML/CFT requirements.
- Strategic partnerships ‚Äî building bridges between DeFi protocols, fintechs, and global financial institutions.

patents.title: Programmatic Generation and Optimization of Images for a Computerized Graphical Advertisement Display
patents.subtitle: US US20190114678A1 ¬∑ Issued Jan 26, 2021
patents.description: A computer receives a request for graphical display source code for a computerized graphical advertisement display, and retrieves seed images including a plurality of seed image features. The computer generates candidate images based on the one or more seed images, where the computer alters a first aspect of a seed image to generate an altered seed image having a plurality of altered seed image features and the computer alters a second aspect of the altered seed image to generate a candidate image having a plurality of candidate image features. The computer generates candidate image scores based upon a context of the advertisement display and the plurality of candidate image features. The computer selects an image from the candidate images based on the candidate image scores and generates the graphical display source code based on the selected image, a size of the advertisement display, and display capabilities of the user device.

patents.title: Programmatic Generation and Optimization of Animation for a Computerized Graphical Advertisement Display
patents.subtitle: US US2019114679A1 ¬∑ Issued Mar 3, 2020
patents.description: A computer receives a request for graphical display source code for a computerized graphical advertisement display, and retrieves seed animations including a plurality of seed animation features. The computer generates candidate animations based on the one or more seed animations, where the computer alters a first aspect of a seed animation to generate an altered seed animation having a plurality of altered seed animation features and the computer alters a second aspect of the altered seed animation to generate a candidate animation having a plurality of candidate animation features. The computer generates candidate animation scores based upon a context of the advertisement display and the plurality of candidate animation features. The computer selects an animation from the candidate animations based on the candidate animation scores and generates the graphical display source code based on the selected animation, a size of the advertisement display, and display capabilities of the user device.

about:

I stay close to the work: backends, distributed systems, and product choices that serve real users. I helped grow Sqreen from first employee to Principal Engineer, then led teams at Doctolib and Matera. I also teach at √âcole Centrale Paris. Today I‚Äôm channeling that mix into Konvu.

Focus areas include AI, complex systems design, architecture, SRE topics, and team management.

We‚Äôre hiring great builders. Got a name? Send it! If not, pitch me your best sci-fi or fantasy book suggestion, or just ask what I‚Äôm reading this week üöÄ

experiences.title: Co-Founder & CTO
experiences.jobDescription:
Konvu is building agentic vulnerability management. We are shipping AI agents that are reasoning like seasoned security engineers, providing evidence for every decision, and plugging into existing developer and security workflows. Ongoing work:

- Designing and evolving the analysis pipeline (both static & runtime), producing auditable exploitability decisions.
- Building the agent framework, enforcing reproducible tool use and evidence-driven analysis.
- Integrating recommendations within scanners, CI, and issue trackers to avoid rip-and-replace.
- Scaling the system to process enterprise-scale backlogs with predictable throughput.
- Hiring and coaching the early team & setting engineering practices 
- Partnering with customers and design partners, closing the loop from pilot signals to product improvements.

We are backed by $5.8M from top US and EU investors and supported by the builders of Docker, Vanta, Dependabot, Sumo Logic, and more. We are looking for great builders to join us on this journey; please reach out :)

experiences.title: VP of Engineering
experiences.jobDescription:
Matera is a PropTech Saas company that allows co-owners to manage their buildings themselves without the services of a professional property manager.

Joined Matera to help scale up and organize the growing engineering team. Unfortunately, the economy didn't agree with this, and so we took another path! We had to shrink the organization.

Still, as VP of engineering, I worked on structuring the team, particularly:
- Having better predictability in delivery
- Clarifying our engineering ladder
- Improving our performance review process 
- Creating a mentoring program (fun fact: 50% of Matera eng team comes from non-traditional backgrounds)

I also had a lot of fun contributing some of my past Rails/SRE expertise and mentoring our senior engineers directly!

experiences.title: Senior Engineering Manager
experiences.jobDescription:
Doctolib is the largest e-health company in Europe.

Our core mission is to make our healthcare systems more human, efficient, and connected!

Doctolib offers a full suite of online services for doctors & hospitals to manage the healthcare process (Booking, Video consultation, Electronic Health Record & Prescription system).

As a Senior Engineering Manager, I started by taking over the Marketing Performance subdomain and directly managed two teams (Doctor Marketing, Scale Customer Engagement Process).

After a few months, I was picked out to lead the Platform subdomain in the Platform Engineering Efficiency Reliability domain. This subdomain is tasked with supporting the whole technical team by maintaining our internal system and providing ready-to-use platform subproducts. The subdomain includes the:
- Developer eXperience team (in charge of our Monolith CI and developer experience),
- Notification Traffic Control team (tasked with creating & maintaining a system to send all our transactional SMS, Push, EMail notifications),
- Capsule team (shaping a better experience for all our mobile iOS/Android & desktop Electron.js development),
- ETL as a Platform group (supporting our ETL developer experience),
- MLE/OPS group (investigation how to better integrate ML & engineering),
- and finally the upcoming Experimentation Platform team (build internal tooling for easy product experimentation).

We are constantly hiring! Feel free to contact me or simply go to https://about.doctolib.fr/jobs

experiences.title: Principal Engineer
experiences.jobDescription:
Working on the future of security!

As the very first employee of Sqreen, I shaped most of the architecture. From our first agent development in Ruby, our dashboard, to our Python backend.

I then continued to work transversely across our write-heavy infrastructure ensuring we align toward a single technological vision that I shaped with our team. I was also very involved and interested in making Sqreen engineering a top-notch team delivering a great product. We had a simple objective, to get you the best security product you have ever used!

As a blooming team, we designed, debugged & fine-tune this SaaS production system that monitored & protects an ever-growing customer base. 

I also previously lead the team of people who focused more on our backend. This included its development, its operations on AWS & our data science activities.

Our technology playground: Python, AWS, MongoDB, DynamoDB, Kinesis, Docker & much more

In February 2021, Datadog and Sqreen signed a definitive acquisition agreement (terms undisclosed)

headline: Co-founder @ IPaidThat / Business Angel & Advisor
about:
I have worked in Digital Advertising since 2008 and I still think it's an amazing field for software engineers to work in, as it has a lot of challenges because of the constant evolution and thrive to achieve "better" advertising. This is exactly why I was never bored to work in this field and why I would be happy to continue work in it.

Aside from being an engineering, I am a foodie and beer lover, I also enjoy cooking and love skiing!
